revisions.rev:
{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1969 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = 12 | APRank = 11 | Record = 9-2-0 | ConfRecord = 6-1-0 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Bob Devaney]] | HCYear = 8th | OffCoach = [[Tom Osborne]] | OCYear = 1st | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = [[I formation]] | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = Big 8 Co-Champions
Sun Bowl Champions | BowlTourney = [[Sun Bowl]] vs. [[1969 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia]] | BowlTourneyResult = W 45-6 | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1969 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1969 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1969 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Bob Devaney]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. In his first year as [[offensive coordinator]], [[Tom Osborne]] instituted the [[I formation]]. The team started 2-2, then won their final six regular season games to tie for the conference championship. They were invited to the [[Sun Bowl]] in [[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]], where they decisively beat the [[1969 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia Bulldogs]] to finish the season at 9-2. The strong finish in 1969 led to consecutive [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national championships]] for the Huskers in [[1970 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|1970]] and [[1971 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|1971]]. ==Schedule== {{Cite web |url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1969 |title =Football - 1969 Wingbacks||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1962-88||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''Mike Corgan'''|||Running Backs||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-82||[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |- |'''[[Monte Kiffin]]'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1967-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Warren Powers'''|||Defensive Backs||align="center"| ||align="center"|1969-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Boyd Epley'''|||Head Strength Coach||align="center"|1969||align="center"|1969-2003||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |} ==Game notes== ===USC=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#5 USC at Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#5 [[1969 USC Trojans football team|USC]]''' | Host = Nebraska | V1 = 7| V2 = 14| V3 = 7| V4 = 3 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 14 | Date = 1969-09-20 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,058 }} {{AFB game box end}} USC had a fight on their hands, despite jumping out to an early 14-0 lead. Nebraska scrambled back and drew up within 7 points in the 4th quarter with 3:40 to go. The Cornhuskers again got the ball back with enough time to score, but USC intercepted and converted the turnover into a field goal in the final seconds to decide the outcome. {{-}} ===Texas A&M=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Texas A&M at Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1969|school=Texas A&M University|team=Texas A&M Aggies|title=Texas A&M}} | Host = '''Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-09-27 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,331 }} {{AFB game box end}} The Cornhuskers put up a touchdown in each of the first two quarters before Texas A&M was somehow able to bottle them up, but the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] had already established that the Aggies would get nothing on the day, and the 14 Nebraska points were carried for the win. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Nebraska at Minnesota''' [box score] | Visitor = '''Nebraska''' | Host = [[1969 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | V1 = 0| V2 = 14| V3 = 14| V4 = 14 | H1 = 7| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-10-04 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium (University of Minnesota)|Memorial Stadium]], [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 52,136 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska QB [[Jerry Tagge]] broke a record while taking apart Minnesota in Minneapolis. The 587 total Cornhusker yards was the second highest total in school history, and his 219 air yards and 82 ground yards rang up to 301 on the day, easily breaking the previous record of 264 yards set in 1951 and tied in 1967. The game started in doubt as Minnesota struck first and forced Nebraska to a 14-14 tie at the half, but there would be no further scoring from the Golden Gophers to answer the additional 28 Nebraska points posted after the half. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#20 Nebraska at #7 Missouri''' [box score] | Visitor = #20 Nebraska | Host = '''#7 {{cfb link|year=1969|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}}''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 7| H3 = 3| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-10-11 | Location = [[Faurot Field]], [[Columbia, Missouri]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 60,500 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska attempted to bring a fight to Columbia to go along with their new #20 ranking, but after Missouri went up 7-0, it did not help that the Cornhuskers turned over a fumble to Missouri which was converted into 7 more points before the half. Nebraska managed to avoid the shutout with a 3rd quarter touchdown but could not overcome Missouri's defense to score again, and subsequently fell back out of the polls. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Kansas at Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1969|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | Host = '''Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 7| V3 = 7| V4 = 3 | H1 = 6| H2 = 8| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1969-10-18 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,667 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska PK Paul Rogers set a Nebraska and Big 8 record with a 55 yard 1st quarter field goal to open the scoring. It was a fierce back-and-forth game, though Nebraska ran ahead by 14 only to have Kansas tie it up in the 3rd and pull ahead with a field goal in the 4th. The Cornhuskers came through, however, putting in the game-winning touchdown with just 1:22 left to play. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Oklahoma State at Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1969|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | Host = '''Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 3| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 6| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-10-25 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,421 }} {{AFB game box end}} The defensive struggle of the day kept the scores low and the game in doubt late, as Nebraska held only a 10 point lead to start the 4th quarter, but the defenses held on both sides and the Cornhuskers got the win. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#18 Colorado at Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #18 [[1969 Colorado Buffaloes football team|Colorado]] | Host = '''Nebraska''' | V1 = 7| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 3| H2 = 7| H3 = 10| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-11-01 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,084 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska's 13 point margin of victory was directly attributable to the school record 3 interceptions by Dana Stephenson, two of which were subsequently converted into touchdowns, giving Nebraska the upset win. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Iowa State at #20 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1969|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | Host = '''#20 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 3| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 10| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-11-08 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,107 }} {{AFB game box end}} Iowa State was held to only 27 yards on the ground in front a Memorial Stadium homecoming crowd, as Nebraska held the Cyclones to just a 2nd quarter field goal on their way to the win. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#17 Nebraska at Kansas State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#17 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1969 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]] | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 3| V4 = 7 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1969-11-15 | Location = [[Bill Snyder Family Football Stadium|KSU Stadium]], [[Manhattan, Kansas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 40,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} The [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] allowed Kansas State a touchdown early on, but closed the door for the rest of the game. The Cornhusker offense needed that support, as they were not able to put up their own points until splitting the uprights with a field goal late in the 3rd, and very much needed the touchdown punched in about 10 minutes later to pull ahead for the victory. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#16 Nebraska at Oklahoma''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#16 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1969 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] | V1 = 14| V2 = 3| V3 = 13| V4 = 14 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1969-11-22 | Location = [[Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium|Oklahoma Memorial Stadium]], [[Norman, Oklahoma]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 53,500 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska fought from behind to deliver Coach Devaney's first win in Norman, a convincing win in which the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] held the season's [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Steve Owens (American football)|Steve Owens]] to just 71 yards with no touchdowns, breaking his 17 game touchdown streak. {{-}} ===Georgia=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#14 Nebraska vs Georgia''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#14 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1969 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia]] | V1 = 18| V2 = 0| V3 = 14| V4 = 13 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 6 | Date = 1969-12-20 | Location = [[Sun Bowl Stadium]], [[El Paso, Texas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 31,728 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska opened the day with four straight 1st quarter field goals, setting new Nebraska and Big 8 records in the process, which was the beginning of Georgia being left far behind. By the time the Bulldogs found the scoreboard on a 4th quarter touchdown, the merely closed the gap to 6-38, which the Cornhuskers then answered with one more touchdown before the final whistle. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{seealso|1969 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- ! Poll !! Pre !! Wk 1 !! Wk 2 !! Wk 3 !! Wk 4 !! Wk 5 !! Wk 6 !! Wk 7 !! Wk 8 !! Wk 9 !! Wk 10 !! Wk 11 !! Wk 12 !! Final |- style="text-align:center;" !
